div.p: Abstract-Hyperspectral images (HSIs) are inevitably corrupted by mixture noise during their acquisition process, in which various kinds of noise, e.g., Gaussian noise, impulse noise, dead lines, and stripes, may exist concurrently. In this paper, mixture noise removal is well illustrated by the task of recovering the low-rank and sparse components of a given matrix, which is constructed by stacking vectorized HSI patches from all the bands at the same position. Instead of applying a traditional nuclear norm, a nonconvex low-rank regularizer, i.e., weighted Schatten p-norm (WSN), is introduced to not only give better approximation to the original low-rank assumption but also to consider the importance of different rank components. The resulted nonconvex low-rank matrix approximation (LRMA) model falls into the applicable scope of an augmented Lagrangian method, and its WSN minimization subproblem can be efficiently solved by generalized iterated shrinkage algorithm. Moreover, the proposed model is integrated into an iterative regularization schema to produce final results, leading to a completed HSI restoration framework. Extensive experimental testing on simulated and real data shows, both qualitatively and quantitatively, that the proposed method has achieved highly competent objective performance compared with several state-of-the-art HSI restoration methods.

div.head: Index Terms-Hyperspectral image (HSI), low-rank matrix approximation (LRMA), restoration, weighted Schatten p-norm (WSN).
I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: H YPERSPECTRAL imaging (HSI) has been attracting great research interests in the field of remote sensing in recent years because of its wide range of applications in geography, agriculture, and military [1]- [3]. Unfortunately, during the capturing procedure, due to various factors, including sensor saturation, photon effects, quantization errors, transmission errors, and calibration errors, the HSI is usually impaired by several types of noise, e.g., Gaussian noise, impulse noise, dead lines, and stripes, rendering the images unsuitable for further applications, such as HSI unmixing, image classification, and object detection [4]- [6]. Therefore, HSI denoising has become an essential preprocessing step for improving the performance of subsequent applications.

Many different denoising methods have been proposed for hyperspectral imagery until now. Inspired by prospective results achieved by gray-level image denoising methods, such as nonlocal mean [48], K-SVD [38], BM3D [33], LSSC [39], NCSR [40], and SAIST [36], the HSI data can be denoised straightforwardly using those methods band by band. However, denoising in this way is always not satisfying since the correlation among all the spectral bands has been ignored. To take account of the correlation, tensor algebra is introduced into HSI denoising by treating HSI as a hypercube. As two important tensor decompositions TUCKER3 and PARAFAC play significant roles in analyzing tensors, researchers have proposed several representative tensor based HSI denoising methods, which combine multidimensional Wiener filter with either TUCKER3 [7], [8] or PARAFAC [5].

Beyond merely using correlation among bands, many researchers are more inclined to jointly consider the spatial and spectral information to remove noise efficiently. For instance, Othman et al. [9] proposed a spatial-spectral wavelet shrinkage method working in the spectral derivative domain for HSI denoising. It took advantage of the dissimilarity of the signal regularity from both spatial and spectral dimensions. In [10], a 2-D discrete cosine transform (DCT) is utilized to sparsify the image along the spatial dimension as well as 1-D DCT to sparsify the image across the spectral domain. To remove the impulse noise, in [11], both spatial redundancy and spectral correlation are captured to formulate denoising as an l 1 -norm regularized l 1 -norm data fidelity minimization problem. In [12], an HSI denoising method is designed by utilizing a spectral-spatial adaptive total variation model, where the noise differences in spectral domain and structural information in spatial domain were both considered. By observing that noise distributions in spatial and spectral views were different, in [13], a strategy of fusing denoised results from both views is employed to further improve the performance. In [14], Zhong and Wang retorted to capture the dependence across spatial and spectral neighbors by using a multiple-spectral-band conditional random field model under a unified probabilistic framework. Moreover, other advanced techniques, including the nonlocal similarity [15], principal component analysis (PCA) [16], anisotropic diffusion [17], multiresolution wavelet analysis [21], sparse and lowrank penalties [19], [20], matrix decomposition/factorization [54], [55], and multitask sparse matrix factorization [18], have been adopted for designing different HSI denoising methods. Nevertheless, all the methods mentioned earlier are designed to handle at most two kinds of noise, i.e., Gaussian noise, impulse noise, or hybrid Gaussian-impulse noise.

In real-world applications, HSI data usually corrupted by a combination of various kinds of noise, such as Gaussian noise, impulse noise, dead lines, and stripes. Hence, there is a need to simultaneously remove all these types of noise. Fortunately, recent years have witnessed the remarkable success of the low-rank technique for mixture noise removal. In [22], the low-rank property of the image matrix was explored by rearranging 3-D patch cube in the same position through all the bands as a 2-D matrix. The bilateral-random-projection-based algorithm, namely "Go Decomposition" (GoDec) [25], was used to explicitly enforce rank r and cardinality k constraints for low-rank and sparse components, respectively. However, this model cannot capture the intrinsic low-rank part of the HSI data, and the optimal values of the rank r and cardinality k are difficult to determine. By sharing the similar idea, in [23], randomized singular value decomposition (RSVD) [24] is used to solve the low-rank matrix approximation (LRMA) problem with an additional noise-adjusted iteration strategy. Similar to [22], the rank r also needed to be predefined. Different from the patchwise LRMA model mentioned earlier, in [26], a lowrank property is acquired through the pixel vectors in spectral domain (e.g., stacking all band values in the same position into a vector). By gathering similar pixel vectors in a local neighborhood into a matrix, the low-rank priori can be explored. Although reasonably effective, it was only designed for hybrid Gaussian-Laplacian noise, which resulted in undesired performance for certain outliers such as dead lines and stripes.

In this paper, we present an iterative HSI restoration method for mixture noise removal based on LRMA, where the lowrank regularization is induced by a nonconvex rank constraint namely weighted Schatten p-norm (WSN). The main ideas and contributions of the proposed method are threefold. First, the low-rank property of HSI data is explored by the robust PCA (RPCA) with explicitly Gaussian noise modeling. Unlike the hard rank and cardinality constraints provided by GoDec, the extended RPCA model can capture intrinsic rank of HSI data, as well as recover the sparse and Gaussian noise component more accurately.

Second, a new low-rank regularizer WSN is introduced into LRMA. The resulting model, which is referred to as WSN-LRMA, not only takes unequal treatments to different rank components, leading to flexibility in dealing with noise removal but also gives better approximation to the original low-rank assumption, getting better denoising results theoretically and practically. Such a kind of nonconvex LRMA is extremely difficult to solve. Fortunately, based on our previous work [31], the objective function of WSN-LRMA can be efficiently optimized. To the best of our knowledge, this kind of a regularizer has never been considered in HSI denoising before. Furthermore, we also give a theoretical convergence analysis of the proposed WSN-LRMA.

Third, the proposed method is integrated into an iterative regularization schema, in which the noise level is estimated and updated automatically, leading to a self-adjusted restoration framework for HSI data. Extensive experimental testing shows, both qualitatively and quantitatively, that the proposed method can effectively remove the mixture noise and recover details of the original scene compared with many state-of-the-art methods.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we motivate the proposed WSN-LRMA model in detail and demonstrate its superiority compared with the traditional model. In Section III, we give an optimization algorithm to solve the proposed model, analyze its convergence, and further improve performance by constructing an iterative regularization algorithm. The experimental results are shown in Section IV, and we conclude the proposed method and discuss the future direction in Section V.

div.head: A. Intrinsic Low Rank in HSI
div.p: Suppose that the latent number of clean spectral endmembers in the HSI subcube is r; its corresponding patch matrix A can be formulated as A = MD T , where the columns of A are constructed by converting the patch in each band to a vector and stacking all those vectors together (as illustrated in Fig. 1), D ∈ R B×r + is the latent end-member matrix with each column denoting a clean spectral end-member, and M ∈ R wh×r + is the abundance matrix. Since the number of endmembers r is commonly relatively small, i.e., r wh or r B (as shown in the SVD plot in Fig. 1, only a few singular values are greater than zero), as well as the value of r is usually unknown, we refer to this property as the intrinsic low-rank constraint. The remainder of this section will describe how to capture the intrinsic rank more accurately by using the extended RPCA model and the proposed low-rank regularizer.

div.head: B. Low-Rank and Sparse Decomposition in HSI Degradation Model
div.p: HSIs, as pointed out in the literature [22], [23], can always be degraded through the acquisition process by a mixture of different kinds of noise, which typically consists of Gaussian noise, impulse noise, dead lines, and stripes. As a result, the HSI degradation model can be described as
div.formula: d = a + e + n(1)
div.p: where a denotes the latent HSI, d is the observed corrupted HSI, e represents the mixture of impulse noise, dead lines, and stripes, and the last term n is the Gaussian noise. All the images d, a, e, and n are 3-D cubes with a same size of M × N × B. By adopting the patch-based restoration schema, the HSI can be divided into overlapped subcubes, and the restoration can be done for each subcube sequentially. Concretely, for the subcube centered at the pixel (i, j) with a size of w × h × B, degradation model (1) can be expressed as follows:
div.formula: d (i,j) = a (i,j) + e (i,j) + n (i,j) . (2
div.p: By rearranging all 3-D subcubes into 2-D matrices (as illustrated in Fig. 1) and omitting the subscript, the degradation model can be transformed into the following matrix form:
div.formula: D = A + E + N(3)
div.p: where matrices D, A, E, and N with a size of wh × B correspond to d, a, e, and n, respectively. To design a lowrank-based HSI restoration method, in [22], the GoDec model proposed in [25] is adopted to capture the "low-rank + sparse" decomposition approximately as follows:
div.formula: min A,E N F = D-A-E F , s.t. rank(A) ≤ r, card(E) ≤ k
div.p: (4) where r and k, both of which are required for predefined, denote the upper bound of the rank of A and the cardinality of E, respectively, and • F is the Frobenius norm. However, the values of r and k need to be predefined rather than be intrinsically determined by the content of matrix A, let alone be different for subcubes at different locations. To capture the intrinsic rank, the RPCA [27], [28] is usually applied to construct a LRMA model, which can be formulated as
div.formula: min A,E A * + λ E 1 s.t. D = A + E(5)
div.p: where
div.formula: A * + λ E 1 s.t. D = A + E + N, N F ≤ η (6)
div.p: where η > 0 denotes the Gaussian noise level. It is worth noting that both (5) and ( 6) are different since the Gaussian matrix N is explicitly constructed. Similar formulation can be found in [29], in which it is stated that this model can unify the classical PCA and the RPCA by considering both sparse errors and entrywise noise in the measurement. Moreover, modeling noise matrix N in an explicit way is more suitable for embedding into the proposed iterative regularization schema since the Gaussian noise variance would be explicitly estimated and updated during the iteration of the restoration process. Indeed, as shown in Section III-B, the value of η decreases in iterative regularization, which will help estimate low-rank component A more accurately. This is the motivation of introducing the iterative regularization schema. Furthermore, nuclear norm minimization (NNM) tends to overshrink the rank components, as well as treats different rank components equally [31], [41], which will be discussed in detail in the following. Therefore, a more flexible low-rank regularizer, namely the WSN, which is proposed in our previous work [31], is adopted to replace the traditional nuclear norm to improve the performance of low-rank approximation.

div.head: B. Iterative Hyperspectral Image Restoration
div.p: Here, we explain how to integrate the proposed WSN-LRMA model into an iterative framework to construct an effective restoration method. Here, we first determine the weights for WSN in (7). Let δ j (A) denote the jth solution of ( 14), an intuitive way for setting weights is that the weight should be inversely proportional to δ j (A), then, we have
div.formula: w j = β √ B (δ j (A) + ε) (23
div.p: where ε is set to 10 -16 to avoid dividing by zero, and β = 2 √ 2η 2 , in which η 2 denotes noise variance. Here, we provide a reasonable explanation for this weight setting. According to the studies on wavelet-based image denoising [36], [37], the thumb rule for choosing the threshold τ = 2 √ 2σ 2 w /σ x is under the assumption that wavelet coefficients observe independent and identically distributed Laplacian distribution, where σ w is the noise variance, and σ x denotes the standard deviation of wavelet coefficients. The value of threshold needs to be inversely proportional to σ x such that the major components of data can be preserved since the major energy are kept only in the first few components in Laplacian distribution. In our weight setting, the empirical distribution of δ j (A) can also be approximately modeled by a Laplacian distribution as the curve of singular values of hyperspectral data presents Laplacian distribution, which is demonstrated in Fig. 1(b). Therefore, an intuitive way for setting weights is that the weight should be inversely proportional to δ j (A), leading to a nondescending order of w i . Such a kind of weights will make sure that the components with larger singular values should be penalized less than smaller ones; hence, the preservation of major data components can be guaranteed.
Since δ j (A) is unavailable at first, it can be initialized by
div.formula: δ j (A) = max σ 2 j (D) -Bη 2 , 0(24)
div.p: where σ j (D) denotes the jth singular value of matrix D.

div.p: where α is a relaxation parameter (we set α = 0.1 in all the experiments). Inspired by this iterative scheme, the estimation of noise variance can be updated by

where γ is a scaling factor controlling the reestimation of noise variance. An intuitive explanation of ( 25) and ( 26) is as follows. As the iteration begins, only strong signals (with large singular values) can survive generalized soft-thresholding (GST) and contribute to the restored result x(k-1) i ; however, partially recovered signal will be fed back to the noisy observation via (25), which helps lower the estimation of noise. In return, weaker signals containing useful image details can be identified and added back to the signal estimation. As the iteration progresses, one can observe that the estimated noise variance monotonically decreases [as shown in (26)]; meanwhile, image structures are progressively recovered until the convergence.

By applying the given procedures to each subcube and aggregating all filtered patches together band by band, the final reconstructed image x can be obtained. In the patchbased restoration method, the image patches are sampled with overlapping regions, and most of the pixels are covered by several restored patches. The value of each pixel in each band of HSI is then determined by taking the average of the restored patches at this pixel. Such a kind of operation is referred to as the patch aggregation, which is used to suppress the possible artifacts in the neighborhood of the boundaries of patches. The whole denoising algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 3. Moreover, the performance gain from iterative regularization is shown in Fig. 3, where the values of mean peak signal-to-noise ratio [the definition can be found in (27)] is increasing during the iterative regularization on the simulated data.

div.head: IV. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS AND ANALYSIS
div.p: This section presents extensive experimental validation of the proposed HSI restoration method on both simulated and real data sets. To this end, both qualitative and quantitative methods are used to evaluate the performance of the proposed method in comparison with several state-of-the-art methods. To promote the culture of reproducible research, source codes and experimental results accompanying this paper can be achieved at https://sites.google.com/site/yuanxiehomepage/.

div.head: A. Simulated Experiments
div.p: To quantitatively evaluate the performance of the proposed method, we generated two degraded HSIs with different degrees of noise-level. The Hyperspectral Digital Imagery Collection Experiment (HYDICE) image of the Washington DC Mall, which contains 191 spectral bands with 1208 × 307 pixels per band, is used as the ground truth in our simulated experiment. Similar to [22], because of the page limitation, only a subregion (256 × 256 × 191) of the whole HSI is used in our experiment as it is presented in Fig. 1. To facilitate the numerical calculation and visualization, all the bands of the HSI are normalized into [0, 1] and then will be stretched to original level after restored. To test the performance of the different restoration The number of dead lines in each bands randomly changes between 3 and 10, and the width of dead lines is from 1 to 3 pixels. 4) Stripes are simulated for the bands from 111 to 150 with the width between 1 and 3 pixels. The number of the stripes in each bands randomly changes from 3 to 10.

Compared with [22], the simulated configuration in our experiment is much more challenging. First, the number of bands affected by spare noise (including impulse noise, dead lines, and stripes) is more than that in [22]. Second, an additional severe Gaussian noise with the variance 0.196 is applied to contaminate all the bands. Recovery under such a difficult condition can thoroughly evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. In all the experiments, as for the step size (which denotes the overlap between two neighborhood subcubes), if we select a very small value, the computational burden will become unacceptable, and if we choose a big value, the result will present artifacts. Therefore, setting the step size to 4 is a good choice like in many patch-based denoising method. As for the number of iterations K, since it can be observed in Fig. 3 that the MPSNR increment becomes quite small after six iterations, we set K = 6 to avoid unnecessary computation. The subcube size and the parameters C, λ and p are set to 20 × 20, 0.007, 1.2, and 0.7, respectively, which will be discussed in detail in Section IV-C. We compare the proposed method with seven representative denoising algorithms: the hard-threshold wavelet denoising (Wavelet) [49], the spectral-spatial adaptive total variation model (SSAHTV) [12], the spectral-spatial view fusion strategy (SSVF) [13], the video block matching 3-D filtering (VBM3D) [50], the GoDec-based low-rank matrix recovery (LRMR) [22], the noise-adjusted LRMA (NAI-LRMA) [23], and the LRMR in low-energy PCA channels (pLRMR) [26]. The respective authors provide the SSAHTV, VBM3D, and SSVF codes, and the parameter settings of the former two methods are similar to [22]; the last one remains unchanged. We have implemented the codes for the other algorithms, which remain faithful to the original papers. It is worth noting that all the LRMR, NAI-LRMA, and pLRMR methods belong to the low-rank-based scheme, which means a comprehensive comparison in our experiment.

a) Visual quality comparison: In terms of visual quality, some representative bands of restored HSI obtained by different methods are presented in Figs. 45678. As a certain degree of noise still exists in Fig. 4(e) (pLRMR), the best approximation is achieved by the proposed method.

It can be observed that, for almost all the bands, the PSNR and SSIM values of the proposed method (denoted by the red curves) are higher than those of the other seven methods under both moderate Furthermore, to conduct quantitative comparison thoroughly, the spectral signatures are also calculated for all the methods. Fig. 10 demonstrates the spectral signatures of pixel (200, 53), which belongs to the roof class, under moderate noise case. The horizontal axis of figure represents spectral band numbers, and the vertical axis denotes digital-number values. It is obvious that the curve shape of the spectral signatures acquired by the proposed method [see Fig. 10(j)] closely resembles that of the spectral signatures in the noise-free spectrum, which can be further confirmed by the difference in the spectral signatures between the noise-free and the restored results, as illustrated in Fig. 11, where the flattest curve means the best restoration result. Similar results can be found in Figs. 12 and 13 for other pixels and noise levels.

div.head: B. Real Data Experiments
div.p: Here, three real-world HSI data sets with varying degrees of mixture noise are used in our experiment to evaluate the performance of the proposed method. Two HYDICE data sets called Urban and Terrain have similar degrees of corruption, i.e., most of the bands are clean but with only a few ones being contaminated by mixture noise: severe noise mixed by Gaussian noise, impulse noise, and stripes in Fig. 14(a); severe noise mixed by Gaussian noise, dead lines, and stripes in Fig. 15(a); and moderate noise mixed by Gaussian noise, dead lines, and stripes in Fig. 16(a). The other hyperspectral sequence, which is referred to as Australia, is obtained from the Earth Observing-1 (EO-1) Hyperion data set, where most of bands contain Gaussian noise, and what is more, about one third of bands are heavily corrupted by mixture noise, e.g., band 88 simultaneously contains the severe Gaussian noise and many stripes, as shown in Fig. 17 In real data experiments, the parameters of all the methods are fixed for all the data sets. The parameters of the proposed method has been mentioned in Section IV-A. The regularization parameters in both SSAHTV and SSVF are set to 5. For the VBM3D method, the noise variation set to 15, and the same preprocessing step has been adopted to handle impulse noise as done in [51]. The upper bound values of the rank r and cardinality k in LRMR are set to 4 and 4000, respectively. For the NAI-LRMA, we choose the decay parameter c = 5 and iteration factor δ = 0.4; other parameters are the same with LRMR. For the pLRMR method, the number of clusters k = 50 is adopted in the k-means algorithm.

a) HYDICE urban data set: This HSI with original size of 304 × 304 × 210 can be downloaded online at http://www. erdc.usace.army.mil/. Similar to [22], the final test data is cut to 304 × 304 × 189 since several bands polluted by atmosphere and water absorption have been removed. The seven best results in visual quality are illustrated in Fig. 14 for the sake of space limits, and similar rule is also applied to other test data sets. The methods VBM3D, SSAHTV, LRMR, and ours can remove such a kind of badly mixture noise. However, the results obtained by VBM3D and SSAHTV tend to oversmooth, incurring information loss in local details (highlighted in green windows). The result of LRMR presents blur effect, which can be clearly seen in the yellow dashed boxes and zoomed windows in Figs. 14 and and NAI-LRMA, some stripes can be eliminated, whereas Gaussian noise and parts of dead lines still exist. Even for LRMR, dead lines cannot be removed thoroughly, leaving some fractions in restored result [see Fig. 16(f)]. The visual comparison confidently indicates that the proposed method outperforms the other methods on Terrain data set. Here, we give a reasonable explanation: the WSN-LRMA model can well preserve the major data components as well as achieve accurately LRMA, which means that sharp local details could be faithful recovered, and the separation between low-rank part and sparse part would become easy. Furthermore, estimating η iteratively will help suppress Gaussian noise more effectively.

c) EO-1 Hyperion Australia data set: The EO-1 Hyperion L1R-level Australia data set is selected for our third real data experiment. This Hyperion image is captured on 4 December 2010 with the location at Australia. The original image is of size 256 × 3858 × 242 and can be downloaded online at http://remote-sensing.nci.org.au/. After removing the overlapping bands between visual near-infrared and shortwave infrared ranges, there are 150 bands remaining for restoration. For simplicity, the final test image is cut to the size of 256 × 400 × 150. It is obvious that SSVF, pLRMR, and NAI-LRMA fail to remove stripes, whereas VBM3D, SSAHTV, and LRMR can partly handle such noise but with effects of artifacts [see Fig. 17(b) and (f)] and oversmooth [see Fig. 17(c)]. Only the proposed method achieves a desirable result, as illustrated in Fig. 17(h), in which the farmlands and hills can be found clearly. Even more noticeable differences are shown in Fig. 18; as for handling the dead lines, all the restored results are presented varying degrees of ghost shadow, except for the result of the proposed method.

Moreover, some of the dropped bands, which are severely polluted by noise or totally out of range for visualization, have been put back to test the robustness of the proposed method. Some representative restoration results are shown in Fig. 19, which also demonstrates the excellent performance of the proposed method for handling such heavy noise.

div.head: C. Model Analysis
div.p: We will discuss some critical parameters in the restoration model (12). There are subcube size and parameters C, λ, and p. For the subcube size, its value does not have a large effect on the restoration results in our proposed method. Table II shows the MPSNR and MSSIM values of the results obtained by our proposed method with different subcube sizes under moderate noise level. It can be observed that WSN-LRMA is not very sensitive to the size of the HSI subcube, except for the size 8, and we choose w = h = 20 for it achieving the best result. The proposed method with a too small patch size cannot capture a meaningful image local content, leading to an undesirable restoration results. C and λ represent weights for low-rank penalty and sparse penalty, respectively; p is the power related to Schatten norm. For simplicity, we first analyze the restoration performance affected by different C and λ when the power p is fixed. Then, various values of p will be evaluated under the optimal C and λ. Recalling the restoration model ( 12), the parameter C can be absorbed into λ. However, during the procedure of ALM, the low-rank regularization and the sparse regularization are solved separately. Thus, using parameter C explicitly will make the subproblem (14) more flexible in setting the weights for WSN. Fig. 20 presents the quantitative evaluation of different C and λ in the simulated experiment under moderate noise level. It is quite obvious that the shape of all the curves fall into similar pattern, which means that the results of the proposed WSN-LRMA restoration method are robust to the combination of parameters C and λ.

Given the optimal values of C and λ, it is necessary for us to investigate the influence of the changing power p upon the quality of restored results. The MPSNR values in Fig. 21 show the influence on simulated data under both noise levels. In this the power are changing from 0.1 to 1 with an interval 0.1. The of p, which is marked by red circle in Fig. 21 is in accord with the conclusion drawn by [31] since such a choice (p = 0.7) achieves a balance between enforcing low-rank and separating sparse outliers.

Additionally, the computational complexity of the proposed method will be discussed. For a matrix of size h 2 × B, in each iteration of the Algorithm 1, since the SVD actually dominates the main computation of the subproblem ( 14), it needs O(min{h 2 B 2 , h 4 B} + JB) flops, where J denotes the number of iterations in the GST algorithm. Both computational demands for subproblems (15) and (16) are O(h 2 B). Therefore, for each subcube of the HSI data, the amount of K × T × O(min{h 2 B 2 , h 4 B} + JB + 2h 2 B) flops are required for the proposed method, where K is the number of regularization steps in Algorithm 3, and T denotes the number of iterations in ALM.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, a WSN-based LRMA approach has been proposed for HSI restoration with iterative regularization. By transforming the HSI restoration into an LRMA problem, a The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method makes impressively quantitative improvements over state-ofthe-art methods, as well as preserves much better image local structures and details on visual quality. Additionally, as it is known to all, a patch can be naturally represented as a matrix. However, current LRMA methods for HSI restoration always need vectorized operation to change an image patch to a vector, discarding the neighboring relationship inside the patch. In contrast, tensor-based representation can preserve the spatial information much better. Therefore, as a future direction, it is reasonable for us to extend the proposed WSN to the case of low-rank tensor approximation or tensor discriminative analysis such as in [52] and [53], although further adaptations are likely.
